chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of cluster headache
chapter.summary: Covers the primary care management of people with cluster headache or suspected cluster headache.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage someone with suspected cluster headache?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If the person has any red flags for a serious secondary cause of headache:
    • Refer to secondary care (with urgency depending on the clinical situation).
    • For information on red flags see the section on warning features of serious causes of headache in the CKS topic Headache - assessment.
  • If clinical features are consistent with cluster headache refer to/discuss with a neurologist or GP with a special interest in headache all:
    • People presenting with a first bout of cluster headache — confirmation of diagnosis by a specialist is required and may involve neuroimaging. Preventative treatment (such as verapamil) may be considered.
    • People with confirmed cluster headache who have developed new symptoms or signs suggestive of a serious underlying secondary cause.
    • Pregnant or breastfeeding women — all pregnant women with cluster headache should be referred to a specialist in neurology.
  • Manage acute bouts of confirmed cluster headache:
    • If appropriate, offer a subcutaneous or nasal triptan to people aged over 18 years — options include:
      • Sumatriptan by subcutaneous injection (for adult) — initially 6 mg for 1 dose, followed by 6 mg after at least 1 hour if headache recurs (people not responding to the initial dose should not take a second dose for the same attack); maximum 12 mg per day or
      • Sumatriptan by intranasal administration (for adult aged 18–65 years) — initially 10–20 mg, dose to be administered into one nostril, followed by 10–20 mg after at least 2 hours only if the headache recurs (people not responding to the initial dose should not take a second dose for the same attack); maximum 40 mg per day or
      • Zolmitriptan by intranasal administration (unlicensed indication, for adult) — 5 mg dose to be administered as soon as possible after onset into one nostril only, followed by 5 mg after at least 2 hours only if symptoms recur; maximum 10 mg per day.
      • For further information, including contraindications, see the Prescribing section in the CKS topic Migraine.
    • Do not offer paracetamol, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories, opioids, ergots or oral triptans for the acute treatment of cluster headache.
    • Offer short burst oxygen therapy
      • If not contra-indicated, provide 100% oxygen at a flow rate of 12–15 litres per minute via a non-rebreather face mask for 15 to 20 minutes.
      • Home oxygen can be provided through the Home Oxygen Order Form (HOOF).
    • Advise the person on avoidance of triggers:
      • Cluster attacks may be triggered or exacerbated by behaviours such as alcohol consumption and smoking.
      • For further information, see the CKS topics on Alcohol - problem drinking and Smoking cessation.
    • Advise the person on the risk of medication overuse headache
      • People with chronic cluster headache may overuse symptomatic medications to treat attacks and develop medication overuse headache.
      • A headache diary recording frequency, severity, duration and characteristics of attacks can help differentiate between headache types.
      • For further information, see the CKS topic on Headache - medication overuse.
    • Identify and manage comorbidities
      • Several conditions including depression, anxiety, and sleep apnoea may co-exist with cluster headache — ensure that co-morbidities are adequately treated. For further information, see the CKS topics on Depression, Generalized anxiety disorder and Obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome.
    • Provide written and oral patient information on cluster headache and support organizations:
      • Patient information on Cluster Headache is available on the NHS A-Z website.
    • If uncertain about diagnosis/management or first line measures in primary care fail – discuss with a specialist in neurology.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of cluster headache are based on clinical guidelines Guidelines for All Healthcare Professionals in the Diagnosis and Management of Migraine, Tension-Type, Cluster and Medication-Overuse Headache [BASH, 2010], Headaches in over 12s: diagnosis and management (updated November 2015) [NICE, 2012], The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (beta version) [IHS, 2013], Diagnosis and treatment of headache [ICSI, 2013],  British Thoracic Society guidelines for home oxygen use in adults: accredited by NICE [Hardinge, 2015], Guideline for primary care management of headache in adults [Becker, 2015],  and the European Headache Federation consensus on technical investigation for primary headache disorders [Mitsikostas, 2015] and expert opinion in review articles [Miller, 2013; Obermann, 2015; Weaver-Agostoni, 2013; Hale, 2014; Robbins, 2016].

Referral to secondary care
  • The National Institute of Care and Health Excellence (NICE) [NICE, 2012] recommends:
    • Consideration of neuroimaging and specialist assessment in people presenting with a first bout of cluster headache.
    • Referral of all pregnant women with cluster headache to neurology.
  • The British Association for the Study of Headache (BASH) recommend management of cluster headache by specialists who see the disorder frequently [BASH, 2010]. 
Acute treatment of confirmed cluster headache
  • Evidence based treatments for relief of individual cluster attacks include subcutaneous or nasal triptans and oxygen — there is no evidence to support the use of opioids, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories, paracetamol or oral triptans [NICE, 2012; Miller, 2013; Weaver-Agostoni, 2013; Becker, 2015].
  • NICE and BASH recommend that adults with acute attacks of cluster headache are offered oxygen and/or a subcutaneous or nasal triptan [BASH, 2010; NICE, 2012].
    • Triptans
      • The information on dosage of triptans is taken from the British National Formulary — licenced indications and contraindications vary between products [BNF 73, 2017].
      • A Cochrane review (n = 6 studies) concluded from limited data that subcutaneous sumatriptan 6 mg was superior to intranasal zolmitriptan 5 mg or 10 mg for rapid (15 minute) relief of pain due to cluster headache. Oral triptans were not considered appropriate [Law, 2013].
      • BASH recommend sumatriptan 6mg subcutaneously as the treatment of choice, unless contraindicated [BASH, 2010].
    • Oxygen
      • NICE and the British Thoracic Society (BTS) recommend treatment of acute cluster headache with 100% oxygen at a flow rate of at least 12 litres per minute through a non-rebreathing mask and a reservoir bag [NICE, 2012; Hardinge, 2015].
      • NICE also recommend that provision of home and ambulatory oxygen should be arranged — the BTS Home Oxygen Guideline provides detailed evidence-based guidance for the use of home oxygen for patients out of hospital including people with cluster headache [Hardinge, 2015].
Patient education
  • The NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2012] recommends that all people with headache be provided with written and oral patient information on cluster headache and support organizations.
    • Expert opinion in review articles is that patient education is important, and should include discussion on managing or avoiding triggers such as smoking, alcohol and volatile substances [Miller, 2013; Weaver-Agostoni, 2013].
